title: Liberalism and radicalism in Italy
text:
<a href="Liberalism">Liberalism</a> and <a href="radicalism%20%28historical%29">radicalism</a> have played a role in the political history of <a href="Italy">Italy</a> since the country's <a href="Italian%20unification">unification</a>, started in 1861 and largely completed in 1871, and currently influence several leading political parties.
During the first decades of Italy as a united country, the main parliamentary parties included liberals, but it was not until 1877 that the left-wing <a href="Italian%20Radical%20Party">Radical Party</a> was established as the first organized liberal party. The more centrist <a href="Liberals%20%28Italy%29">Liberal Union</a> followed in 1913. Most liberal and radical parties were banned in 1926 under <a href="Benito%20Mussolini">Benito Mussolini</a>'s <a href="Italian%20Fascism">Fascist</a> government.
After <a href="World%20War%20II">World War II</a> and the establishment of the <a href="History%20of%20the%20Italian%20Republic">Italian Republic</a> there have been frequent changes in the configuration of political parties and, for the most part, the representation of liberal and radical views has been split among a number of parties that may also espouse other views. These parties have often been part of governing <a href="coalition">coalition</a>s.
During the so-called "<a href="History%20of%20the%20Italian%20Republic%23The%20%26quot%3BFirst%20Republic%26quot%3B%20%281948%E2%80%931992%29">First Republic</a>" three minor liberal parties were active: the <a href="Italian%20Liberal%20Party">Italian Liberal Party</a> (centre-right), the <a href="Italian%20Republican%20Party">Italian Republican Party</a> (centre-left) and the modern-day <a href="Radical%20Party%20%28Italy%29">Radical Party</a> (left-wing). More recently, liberals have been split primarily among the centre-right <a href="The%20People%20of%20Freedom">The People of Freedom</a>/<a href="Forza%20Italia%20%282013%29">Forza Italia</a> and the centre-left <a href="Democratic%20Party%20%28Italy%29">Democratic Party</a>.
Overview.
In the 19th century both early Italian political groupings, the <a href="Historical%20Right">Historical Right</a> and the <a href="Historical%20Left">Historical Left</a>, were composed of <a href="monarchism">monarchist</a> liberals and functioned mainly as loose <a href="parliamentary%20group">parliamentary group</a>s, while radicals organised themselves as the <a href="Italian%20Radical%20Party">Radical Party</a>, and republicans, who were influenced also by <a href="socialism">socialism</a>, as the <a href="Italian%20Republican%20Party">Italian Republican Party</a>. These two parties had in fact been part of <a href="Historical%20Far%20Left">The Extreme</a>, which included also the <a href="Italian%20Socialist%20Party">Italian Socialist Party</a> and its predecessors.
In 1913 the liberals around <a href="Giovanni%20Giolitti">Giovanni Giolitti</a> joined forces in the <a href="Liberals%20%28Italy%29">Liberal Union</a> and in 1922 the <a href="Italian%20Liberal%20Party">Italian Liberal Party</a> was formed. In that period, other liberal parties emerged: the <a href="Constitutional%20Democratic%20Party%20%28Italy%29">Constitutional Democratic Party</a>, the <a href="Democratic%20Liberal%20Party%20%28Italy%29">Democratic Liberal Party</a> (merger of the Radicals with other liberal groups), and the <a href="Italian%20Social%20Democratic%20Party">Italian Social Democratic Party</a>.
When <a href="Benito%20Mussolini">Benito Mussolini</a>'s <a href="National%20Fascist%20Party">National Fascist Party</a> came to power in 1922, some Liberals and Radicals flirted with Fascism, but, ultimately, a <a href="Italian%20Fascism">Fascist</a> regime was established and all the parties, notably including the Italian Liberal Party and the Italian Republican Party, were banned.
After the end of <a href="World%20War%20II">World War II</a>, both Liberals and Republicans reorganised themselves, followed by more liberal parties in the upcoming decades (notably including the new <a href="Radical%20Party%20%28Italy%29">Radical Party</a>), and, despite their modest results in elections, they were often part of the Italian government, in alliance with <a href="Christian%20Democracy%20%28Italy%29">Christian Democracy</a>. In the 1940s, during the <a href="Italian%20resistance%20movement">resistance movement</a> and the writing of the <a href="Constitution%20of%20Italy">republican Constitution</a>, an important role was played by the <a href="Action%20Party%20%28Italy%29">Action Party</a>, a social-liberal, republican and <a href="liberal%20socialism">liberal-socialist</a> outfit, successor of the <a href="Giustizia%20e%20Libert%C3%A0">Justice and Freedom</a> movement. In this phase the Liberals adhered to <a href="conservative%20liberalism">conservative liberalism</a> and Republicans to <a href="social%20liberalism">social liberalism</a>.
Since 1992–1994, following the "Tangentopoli" scandals, the subsequent "<a href="Mani%20pulite">Mani pulite</a>" inquiries and the resulting shake-up of the Italian party system, the liberal movement has been strongly divided. As a result, a broad group of parties, not all included here, started to use the "liberal" label.
Italian liberals are basically divided between the centre-right <a href="Forza%20Italia%20%282013%29">Forza Italia</a> (successor of the former <a href="Forza%20Italia">Forza Italia</a>, itself primarily a merger of liberal and Christian-democratic forces, and <a href="The%20People%20of%20Freedom">The People of Freedom</a>, which integrated the more conservative <a href="National%20Alliance%20%28Italy%29">National Alliance</a>) and the centre-left <a href="Democratic%20Party%20%28Italy%29">Democratic Party</a> (a merger of social democrats, progressive Christian democrats and social liberals, the latter two mainly organised in <a href="Democracy%20is%20Freedom%20%E2%80%93%20The%20Daisy">Democracy is Freedom – The Daisy</a> in the early 2000s).
Minor liberal parties include, among others, <a href="Civic%20Choice">Civic Choice</a>, the <a href="Italian%20Radicals">Italian Radicals</a> (<a href="Alliance%20of%20Liberals%20and%20Democrats%20for%20Europe%20Party">ALDE Party</a> and <a href="Liberal%20International">Liberal International</a> member), the aforementioned Italian Republican Party (which stretched a long way from the far-left to the centre-right of the <a href="political%20spectrum">political spectrum</a>), and <a href="Act%20to%20Stop%20the%20Decline">Act to Stop the Decline</a> (a party which is the standard-bearer of a more <a href="classical%20liberalism">classical</a>- and <a href="libertarianism">libertarian</a>-oriented form of liberalism). Also the centrist-populist <a href="Italy%20of%20Values">Italy of Values</a> was a member of the ALDE Party, but it is hardly a liberal party.
From 1994 on, most Liberals and several Republicans joined Forza Italia and the other parties of the <a href="House%20of%20Freedoms">House of Freedoms</a> coalition. This is the reason why the term "liberal" is more often used when speaking of the centre-right than the centre-left. A new <a href="Italian%20Liberal%20Party%20%281997%29">Italian Liberal Party</a> was launched in 1997, but, as the Italian Republican Party, it survives as a very minor party. The former two, Civic Choice, Act to Stop the Decline and minor groups joined forces in <a href="European%20Choice">European Choice</a>, with disappointing results, in 2014.
